description: This course serves as an introduction to quantitative aspects of cell and molecular biology. The course will cover several case studies in which quantitative approaches have led to new insights into biological phenomena. Subjects will include gene expression, gene networks, developmental biology, chemotaxis, signaling, and some basic genomics, among other topics.
name: CELL BIOLOGY

values.comments:
This course serves as an introduction to quantitative aspects of cell and molecular
biology. The course covers several case studies in which quantitative approaches have
led to new insights into biological phenomena. Subjects include gene expression, gene
networks, developmental biology, chemotaxis, signaling, and some basic genomics,
among other topics.
Students found the “topics of the lecture fairly interesting.” But some students
were disappointed that the class did not cover “a broad enough scope cell biology.”
Students tended to agree that the class “analyzes biology from a mathematical
perspective” because a lot of the work “required using probability and statistics.”
Students also felt there was a lot of emphasis on translation and transcription.
One student commented that “Dr. Raj teaches with excellence.” Though there
were no complaints about Professor Raj’s teaching, one student commented that “It was
clear that Dr. Raj had not planned what he would teach in the last few weeks of the
course. Several times, we were asked what we were interested in learning the following
week. In addition, he brought in several guest lecturers whose lectures had almost no
relation to what had been covered in the course.”
Students should be prepared to use statistics and MATLAB because they are both
required for most of the assignments. There are no exams but there are homeworks that
take time and there is a final project. A graduate standing or permission from the
instructor is needed in order to take this class.
